Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research - Sediment pathways, sedimentation processes, and structural growth along the Tohoku segment of the Japan subduction margin: Role of megathrust earthquakes
Award.AbstractNarration:
While tectonic activity, climate, sea-level fluctuations, and anthropogenic activity are most often cited as important agents that control sediment transport and depositions, the role of earthquakes as agents of sediment dispersal and accumulation at active margins may be underappreciated. The 2011 Tohoku earthquake at the Japan Trench was one of the largest megathrust ruptures this century. Because the Japanese subduction system is exceptionally well instrumented, an unprecedented wealth of data are accumulating that document pre-seismic, co-seismic, and post-seismic conditions, providing the first opportunity to quantify environmental changes resulting from a megathrust earthquake. This project will integrate the analysis of existing sediment cores and geophysical data collected in the rupture area of the 2011 earthquake to unravel the contributions of coseismic sedimentation to the stratigraphy of the Japan Trench slope. The Japan Trench is the focus of a coordinated, long-term research program in Japan, and results from this study will contribute usefully to future investigations as well as strengthen an existing international collaboration. Japanese colleagues have already provided the Principle Investigators with recently acquired geophysical data and invited one of them to participate in two coring cruises. This project will further the development of underwater paleoseismology, an emerging field compared to land-based paleoseismology. Results from this study will be highly societally relevant as they are expected to contribute to the assessment of seismic hazards at the Japan Trench. They will also be applicable to the assessment of seismic hazards at other oceanic trenches, including three GeoPRISMS's focus sites (Cascadia, Aleutian, and New Zealand trenches) and the deep Puerto Rico Trench.

The Principle Investigators have already initiated collaboration with Japanese scientists to investigate the 2011 event, due to a previously funded NSF-RAPID grant. One of the Principle Investigators participated in two sediment sampling expeditions to the Japan Trench in 2013 aboard the R/V NATSUSHIMA. The preliminary analysis of 31 piston cores collected across the trench slope suggests that some of them sampled deposits from the 2011 event and from prior events. Close inspection of multibeam bathymetric data also suggests that variations in sediment characteristics along the trench are systematically correlated with variations in the morphology of the small frontal prism, the feature at the lower trench slope that absorbs most of the tectonic deformation. This project aims to further explore these results. Specifically, the combined analysis will address the following two questions:

- What are the sedimentary signatures of great earthquakes across a trench slope?
- How do seafloor morphology and tectonic structures affect coseismic sediment dispersal and deposition?

By analyzing the sedimentary record of past earthquakes and their relation to seafloor morphology and tectonic structures, this project will contribute simultaneously to two distinct fields of geoscience: the characterization of coseismic sedimentary processes at active margins and submarine paleoseismology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sediment transport and accumulation across continental margins has long been the focus of scientific investigation. However, the role of earthquakes as agents of sediment dispersal and accumulation may be under-appreciated, and for a good reason: Great offshore earthquakes are rare and brief events and capturing their effects “in the act” is challenging.

 On March 11, 2011, Japan caught the world’s attention with the occurrence of a devastating megathrust earthquake and of the megatsunami that soon followed. Because the Japanese subduction system is densely instrumented, an unprecedented wealth of data became available that documented pre-seismic and co-seismic conditions. This project has integrated the analysis of geophysical data and sediment cores collected by Japan Agency for Marine-Earth Science and Technology (JAMSTEC) within the rupture area of the 2011 earthquake together with the numerical modeling of sediment pathways. The main objectives were to characterize the sedimentary signatures of great earthquakes across a trench slope, and to determine how seafloor morphology and tectonic structures affect co-seismic sediment dispersal and deposition.

 The analysis of sediment cores collected in “slope basins” at 5,000-6,000 m water depth documents the remobilization of the upper few centimeters of sediment as a significant process triggered by the earthquake and its aftershocks. However, numerical modeling suggests that most sediment pathways issued from above 4,000 m water depth generally do not reach the deeper trench axis (> 7,000 m depth) and terminate instead at these small slope basins. It thus implies that sediments accumulating at the axis of the Japan Trench may be mostly derived from the co-seismic erosion of the deep “frontal wedge”, a structure consisting of sediments that are highly deformed by subduction processes near the trench axis. Application of the same numerical method to other subduction zones around the World further suggests that sediment dispersal across trench slopes are affected by both regional time-averaged sedimentation rates and the average gradient of the trench slopes.

 Beyond the investigation of fundamental sedimentation processes at subduction margins, this project has contributed to the emerging field of underwater paleoseismology, the scientific method by which ancient earthquakes can be characterized based on their sedimentary impacts, which is preserved in distinctive layers called “seismites”. By developing a method to help select sites across a trench slopes that are most likely to preserve a continuous record of such seismites, this project will contribute to a better assessment of seismic hazards along the World’s subduction zones, and thus will help with seismic mitigation and preparedness in coastal areas. In particular, results from this project are applicable to the assessment of the seismic hazards associated with the Puerto Rico Trench, one of the deepest trenches in the World, as well as with three focus sites of the NSF-funded GeoPRISMS program: The Cascadia, Aleutian, and New Zealand subduction margins.

 Lastly, this project has strengthened an existing collaboration between American and Japanese scientists, leading to the submission of several other joint proposals. Although none of these other proposals have been funded, it is the intent of the investigators to pursue collaborative projects with Japan in the near future.
